questions.neutral: Is it always this quiet when you come in?

hobby.message: Still folding origami to stay grounded?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Sometimes. Depends on the news cycle.
Just here to unwind tonight. Been hectic.
Don't get out much lately. Too busy.
I dabble in some photography—ever heard of film?
You know, street shots. Captures a lot the city misses.
More BCI whispers than usual lately. Not a surprise.
Caught a few curious street scenes—no big deal.
Stuff's changing though, might change too.
Quiet's nice; space to think, you know?
Besides work, street photography's my thing.
Not the digital stuff—I'm into 35mm film.
Real images, right? City's real truth hidden there.
BCI's messing with signals lately, remember?
Could be why quiet’s got tension now.
Friday, walked past the Council—film jammed.
Hey, at least life captures itself sometimes.
Depends on the vibe; tonight is chill.
I love capturing life here—shooting 35mm film.
Not many do that; digital feels too... clean.
Street's raw, unpredictable—like true art.
Halden's news stirred the BCI and glitches, right?
Out on Friday, city felt like held breath—wild.
Caught flickering streetlights—powerful shot.
Truth in those moments; that's why I stick with film.
Sometimes predictable, sometimes not, like this city.
Photography keeps me grounded; my calm in the storm.
Especially analog, like 35mm, more soul, less static.
Got a stash from before the crackdown on supplies.
Folks feel it—Friday, streets quitely buzzing about Halden.
They’ve tied emotions up in tech. My camera jammed; bizarre.
Meant I was meant to be there; flickering lights told a story.
Like truth echoing through static. That's why film is life.
It varies; calm before the storm tonight, I suppose.
Analog photography—my lens to truth amid noise.
Got hooked young; dad hated it; still stuck with it.
Film is timeless; caught the city's real soul last Friday.
You know, those hidden shots, less digital noise.
Halden's story's woven into our lives, glitches revealed.
Caught a rare shot—flickering lights over the Council.
Life captures the unpredictable; that's why film matters.
hobby_answer: Analog shots don't lie, right? Yeah, still at it.
Just been sticking to the basics, nothing fancy.
It's harder with all these tech issues around, though.
You know, rumors say it's affecting everything lately.
Anyway, not much else to say about it.
Analog shots don't lie, right? True enough.
I like to capture things as they are, no filters.
The recent glitches make it tricky.
It's said things are out of sync everywhere.
Makes you wonder, really.
Analog shots don't lie, right? Yep, that's the magic.
There's a purity to film that digital can't touch.
These days, the static in the system makes everything a guessing game.
I got really excited about a shot, then poof, camera jammed — part of that citywide flicker.
It's like we're all adjusting to these odd beats.
Absolutely, analog shots keep things real.
I think that's why I love it — capturing the truth in a frame.
But, you know, the recent citywide glitches are making even that tough.
Remember Friday night? Had this perfect shot lined up, and then everything went weird.
Like, the street lamps flickered; even my camera jammed. It's all linked, isn't it?
Analog shots don't lie, right? That's my mantra.
The film captures hidden truths — the kind you don't want tampered with.
Fun fact: the city glitches remind me of Halden's death — coincidence?
Friday, I was out shooting, and everything flickered; even my camera jammed during this eerie moment.
It's like these tech glitches are more than just system failures — they weave into our reality.
